case.name: Kim v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2007] FCA 138 (9 March 2007)

citances.sentence: Without an approved nomination the visa applicant cannot meet clause 442.222 and the application cannot succeed. In Tvarkovsky v MIMA (2001) FCA 375 (4 April 2001) the Federal Court held that decisions to refuse nominations for occupational training are reviewable by the Tribunal. In Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 the Federal Court, in its appellate jurisdiction, held that the decision on the nomination in relation to a subclass 442 occupational trainee visa is a separate decision that is not an MRT- reviewable decision and, if it is, it is only reviewable by the nominator. The Court relied upon the fact that a separate decision is made by the delegate that does not fall within any categories prescribed in subsection 338(9), without considering the effect of the lack of a separate legislative process for any such decision outside the criterion for the visa subclass. As it is a judgment of the Federal Court in its appellate jurisdiction, the Tribunal considers itself bound by Kim .

There is no evidence before the Tribunal to indicate that a nomination in respect of the occupational training, either by Sarah's Secret Cosmetics Co or by any other nominator, has been approved by the Minister at the time of the Tribunal's decision. Further, authorities such as Kim v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2007] FCA 138 and, more recently, Suh v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCAFC 42 , suggest that there is no right of review available against the decision not to approve a nomination for the purpose of cl 442.222(1). The Tribunal thus finds that it has no power to review a decision not to approve a nomination.

There is no evidence before the Tribunal to indicate that a nomination in respect of the occupational training, either by CSM Trading Pty Ltd or by any other nominator, has been approved by the Minister at the time of the Tribunal's decision. Further, authorities such as Kim v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2007] FCA 138 and, more recently, Suh v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCAFC 42 , suggest that there is no right of review available against the decision not to approve a nomination for the purpose of cl 442.222(1). The Tribunal thus finds that it has no power to review a decision not to approve a nomination.

There is no evidence before the Tribunal to indicate that a nomination in respect of the occupational training, either by CSM Trading Pty Ltd or by other nominator, has been approved by the Minister at the time of the Tribunal's decision. Further, authorities such as Kim v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2007] FCA 138 and, more recently, Suh v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCAFC 42 , suggest that there is no right of review available against the decision not to approve a nomination for the purpose of cl 442.222(1). The Tribunal thus finds that it has no power to review a decision not to approve a nomination.

The applicant was nominated in this application by Sarah's Secret Cosmetics Co. That nomination has not been approved. There is no evidence before the Tribunal to indicate that a nomination in respect of the occupational training, either by Sarah's Secret Cosmetics Co or by other nominator, has been approved by the Minister at the time of the Tribunal's decision, as required by cl. 442.222(1). Further, authorities such as Kim v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2007] FCA 138 and Suh v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCAFC 42 , suggest that there is no right of review available against the decision not to approve a nomination for the purpose of cl 442.222(1). The Tribunal thus finds that it has no power to review a decision not to approve a nomination. The Tribunal finds that the applicant does not meet cl. 442.221(1).

The applicant was nominated in this application by CSM. That nomination has not been approved. There is no evidence before the Tribunal to indicate that a nomination in respect of the occupational training, either by CSM or by other nominator, has been approved by the Minister at the time of the Tribunal's decision, as required by cl. 442.222(1). Further, authorities such as Kim v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2007] FCA 138 and Suh v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCAFC 42 , suggest that there is no right of review available against the decision not to approve a nomination for the purpose of cl 442.222(1). The Tribunal thus finds that it has no power to review a decision not to approve a nomination. The Tribunal finds that the applicant does not meet cl. 442.221(1).

Authorities such as Kim v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2007] FCA 138 and Suh v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCAFC 42 , suggest that there is no right of review available against the decision not to approve a nomination for the purpose of cl 442.222(1). The Tribunal thus finds that it has no power to review a decision not to approve a nomination.

Authorities such as Kim v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2007] FCA 138 and Suh v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCAFC 42 , suggest that there is no right of review available against the decision not to approve a nomination for the purpose of cl 442.222(1). The Tribunal thus finds that it has no power to review a decision not to approve a nomination.

Without an approved nomination the visa applicant cannot meet clause 442.222 and the application cannot succeed. In Tvarkovsky v MIMA (2001) FCA 375 (4 April 2001) the Federal Court held that decisions to refuse nominations for occupational training are reviewable by the Tribunal. In Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 the Federal Court, in its appellate jurisdiction, held that the decision on the nomination in relation to a subclass 442 occupational trainee visa is a separate decision that is not an MRT- reviewable decision and, if it is, it is only reviewable by the nominator. The Court relied upon the fact that a separate decision is made by the delegate that does not fall within any categories prescribed in subsection 338(9) , without considering the effect of the lack of a separate legislative process for any such decision outside the criterion for the visa subclass. As it is a judgment of the Federal Court in its appellate jurisdiction, the Tribunal considers itself bound by Kim

The applicant confirmed in his oral evidence to the Tribunal that he was nominated by Wilson Transformer Co and that this nomination has not been approved. There is no evidence before the Tribunal to indicate that a nomination in respect of the occupational training, either by Wilson Transformer Co Pty Ltd or by other nominator, has been approved by the Minister at the time of the Tribunal's decision, as required by cl. 442.222(1). Further, authorities such as Kim v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2007] FCA 138 and Suh v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCAFC 42 , suggest that there is no right of review available against the decision not to approve a nomination for the purpose of cl 442.222(1). The Tribunal thus finds that it has no power to review a decision not to approve a nomination. The Tribunal finds that the applicant does not meet cl. 442.221(1).

There is no evidence before the Tribunal to indicate that a nomination in respect of the occupational training, either by Gold Coast Publications Pty Ltd or by other nominator, has been approved by the Minister at the time of the Tribunal's decision. Further, authorities such as Kim v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2007] FCA 138 and, more recently, Suh v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCAFC 42 , suggest that there is no right of review available against the decision not to approve a nomination for the purpose of cl 442.222(1). The Tribunal thus finds that it has no power to review a decision not to approve a nomination.

Without an approved nomination the visa applicant cannot meet clause 442.222 and the application cannot succeed. In Tvarkovsky v MIMA (2001) FCA 375 (4 April 2001) the Federal Court held that decisions to refuse nominations for occupational training are reviewable by the Tribunal. In Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 the Federal Court, in its appellate jurisdiction, held that the decision on the nomination in relation to a subclass 442 occupational trainee visa is a separate decision that is not an MRT- reviewable decision and, if it is, it is only reviewable by the nominator. The Court relied upon the fact that a separate decision is made by the delegate that does not fall within any categories prescribed in subsection 338(9) , without considering the effect of the lack of a separate legislative process for any such decision outside the criterion for the visa subclass. As it is a judgment of the Federal Court in its appellate jurisdiction, the Tribunal considers itself bound by Kim .

Without an approved nomination the visa applicant cannot meet clause 442.222 and the application cannot succeed. In Tvarkovsky v MIMA (2001) FCA 375 (4 April 2001) the Federal Court held that decisions to refuse nominations for occupational training are reviewable by the Tribunal. However, more recently in Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 the Federal Court, in its appellate jurisdiction, held that the decision on the nomination in relation to a Subclass 442 occupational trainee visa is a separate decision that is not an MRT- reviewable decision and, if it is, it is only reviewable by the nominator. The Court relied upon the fact that a separate decision is made by the delegate that does not fall within any categories prescribed in subsection 338(9) , without considering the effect of the lack of a separate legislative process for any such decision outside the criterion for the visa subclass. As it is a judgment of the Federal Court in its appellate jurisdiction, the Tribunal considers itself bound by Kim .

Without an approved nomination the visa applicant cannot meet clause 442.222 and the application cannot succeed. In Tvarkovsky v MIMA (2001) FCA 375 (4 April 2001) the Federal Court held that decisions to refuse nominations for occupational training are reviewable by the Tribunal. However, more recently in Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 the Federal Court, in its appellate jurisdiction, held that the decision on the nomination in relation to a subclass 442 occupational trainee visa is a separate decision that is not an MRT- reviewable decision and, if it is, it is only reviewable by the nominator. The Court relied upon the fact that a separate decision is made by the delegate that does not fall within any categories prescribed in subsection 338(9) , without considering the effect of the lack of a separate legislative process for any such decision outside the criterion for the visa subclass. As it is a judgment of the Federal Court in its appellate jurisdiction, the Tribunal considers itself bound by Kim

Finally, the applicant made a late plea that the Tribunal should have telephoned the witnesses whose evidence it was not prepared to accept. This is a claim that the Tribunal should have made inquiries but it does not pass the test set out in Minister for Immigration v Lee [2007] FCA 138 , which would only make this an obligation where the information is on a critical issue and is readily available and centrally relevant. Otherwise, there is no general duty to inquire; SZHVL v Minister for Immigration [2008] FCA 356 ; Seyfarth v Minister for Immigration [2004] FCA 1713 , MIMIA v SGLB (2004) 207 ALR 12.

There is no evidence before the Tribunal to indicate that a nomination in respect of the occupational training, either by Nolasco Construction or by other nominator, has been approved by the Minister at the time of the Tribunal's decision. Further, authorities such as Kim v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2007] FCA 138 and, more recently, Suh v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2009] FCAFC 42 , suggest that there is no right of review available against the decision not to approve a nomination for the purpose of cl 442.222(1). The Tribunal thus finds that it has no power to review a decision not to approve a nomination.

On 14 April 2009 the Tribunal (differently constituted) wrote to the applicants and the relevant part of the letter is as follows:
You are invited to comment on or respond to information that the Tribunal considers would, subject to any comments or response you make, be the reason, or a part of the reason, for affirming the decisions that are under review. The particulars of the information are:
You have been nominated in connection with your visa application by Citicare Australia Pty Ltd. Information on the Department's file indicates that the nomination application lodged on 20 March 2003 was refused by the Department on 21 March 2003.
This information is relevant to the review because the Tribunal is bound by the decision of the Federal Court of Australia ( Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 (9 March 2007) where Justice Lander found that the decision to refuse the nomination was not an MRT reviewable decision. This means that the Tribunal cannot review the decision to refuse the nomination. Without an approved nomination you cannot meet cl. 442.222 of the Migration Regulations 1994 and your application for the visa cannot succeed. This means that the Tribunal will agree with the Department's decision to refuse to grant you a visa. You are invited to give comments on or respond to the above information in writing.

The Tribunal based its finding on that point on the decision of the Federal Court in Kim v Minister for Immigration & Citizenship [5] , which was a decision on appeal from the Federal Magistrates Court. The Tribunal, in its findings and reasons, said: [17] A recent judgment by the Federal Court in Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 states that the nomination refusal is not reviewable because it is not an MRT reviewable decision. Whilst it is contrary to earlier cases, the Tribunal considers that Kim (No.7) is currently the leading authority on this issue as it is a judgment of the Federal Court in its appellate jurisdiction. [18] There is no evidence that a nomination in respect of occupational training has been lodged and has been approved. Accordingly, the visa applicant cannot meet cl.442.222. [19] Given the findings made above, the Tribunal has no alternative but to affirm the decision under review. [6] Application for Judicial Review

14 However, a decision not to approve a nomination made for the purpose of cl 442.222(1) is not reviewable. Section 338 of the Act specifies what decisions are reviewable by the MRT including, under s 338(9) , decisions which are prescribed for that purpose. A decision not to approve a nomination for the purpose of cl 442.222(1) is neither identified by s 338 nor elsewhere prescribed for that purpose. There was, accordingly, no right of review available against that decision (see also Kim v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2007] FCA 138 ( "Kim" ).

A recent judgement by the Federal Court in Kim v MIAC (2007) FCA 138 states that the nomination refusal is not reviewable because it is not an MRT reviewable decision. Whilst it is contrary to earlier cases, the Tribunal considers that Kim (No. 7) is currently the leading authority on this issue as it is a judgment of the Federal Court in its appellate jurisdiction. A recent judgement by the Federal Court in Kim v MIAC (2007) FCA 138 states that the nomination refusal is not reviewable because it was not an MRT reviewable decision and it was only reviewable at the instigation of the nominator only. Previous decisions of the Federal Court stated that refusal nominations for occupational training are reviewable by the Tribunal (see Tvarkovsky v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (2001) FCA 375 (4 April 2001) and PMA4/2001)).

The Applicant asks the Court to make orders cancelling the Tribunal's decision and requiring the Tribunal to review the application again. The ground upon which she relies is that the Tribunal made an error of law by not reviewing the refusal by the delegate of the Minister of the nomination of her employer. The Applicant claims in her application that despite the decision of the Federal Court in Kim v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [1] the Tribunal was able to review the nomination refusal on the basis of the decision in Tvarkovski v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs [2] . Background The letter told the Applicant: This information is relevant to the review because the Tribunal is bound by the decision of the Federal Court of Australia (Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 (9 March 2007) where Justice Lander found that the decision to refuse the nomination was not an MRT reviewable decision. This means that the Tribunal cannot review the decision to refuse the nomination. Without an approved nomination you cannot meet cl. 442.222 of the Migration Regulations 1994 and your application for a visa cannot succeed. This means that the Tribunal will agree with the Department's decision to refuse to grant you a visa. [5] The Tribunal went on to say: Prior to the decision of Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 , it was considered that decisions to refuse nominations for occupational training were reviewable by the Tribunal (see Tvarkovsky [13] v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (2001) FCA 375 (4 April 2001) and PMA 4/2001)). The Tribunal considers that the applicant has provided evidence indicating that she has ongoing occupational training, comprising her TAFE studies and workplace training. In such circumstances may have approved the nomination for occupational training and considers it unfortunate that it was refused by the delegate given that there was evidence provided to the Department establishing the applicant's ongoing training. However, as previously stated, the Tribunal is unable to review the Department's refusal of the nomination for workplace training made by Strobe Hair. [14]

It is convenient to consider the second ground first and the issues that arise from that ground insofar as it is taken as an assertion that the Tribunal had an obligation to review the refusal of the nomination application as part of its review of the refusal of the visa application. I note that the basis on which the matter was remitted by consent to the Tribunal on 5 March 2007 suggested that the Tribunal had such an obligation. However there is subsequent appellate authority of the Federal Court of Australia to the contrary in Kim v Minister for Immigration and Citizenship [2007] FCA 138 of 9 March 2007. In Kim Lander J considered a Tribunal review of the refusal of an application for the same class of visa in issue in this case (indeed the same subclass) to which the criterion in subclause 442.222 applied where the nomination had been refused by the Department.

In response (dated 2 November 2008) to the Tribunal's invitation, the first named applicant submitted that the Tribunal's interpretation of the Federal Court decision in Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 (Lander J, 9 March 2007) (Kim (No. 7) was incorrect. She also claimed that a decision to refuse an onshore Subclass 442 application is MRT reviewable and that this may include a review of the nomination. The first named applicant did not submit evidence of an approved nomination as requested. Whether the Tribunal has jurisdiction to consider and approve a nomination for the purposes of cl.422.222 has been the subject of diverging views in the Courts. The leading authority on this issue indicates that nominations that are refused are not reviewable by the MRT. In Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 (Lander J, 9 March 2007) (Kim (No. 7) Lander J found that a decision to refuse a nomination is a separate decision and not MRT-reviewable because it is not prescribed under s.338(9) of the Act. Furthermore, if the decision to refuse the nomination was an MRT-reviewable decision, it could only have been reviewable by virtue of s.338(9). If it were so prescribed, only the nominator (that is, the business sponsor or the employer as prescribed persons under s.347(2)(d)) could seek review.

In response (dated 3 October 2008) to the Tribunal's invitation, the first named applicant submitted that the Tribunal's interpretation of the Federal Court decision in Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 (Lander J, 9 March 2007) (Kim (No. 7) is incorrect. The first named applicant also claimed that a decision to refuse an onshore Subclass 442 application is MRT reviewable and that this may include a review of the nomination. Whether the Tribunal has jurisdiction to consider and approve a nomination for the purposes of cl.422.222 has been the subject of diverging views in the Courts. The leading authority on this issue indicates that nominations that are refused are not reviewable by the MRT. In Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 (Lander J, 9 March 2007) (Kim (No. 7) Lander J found that a decision to refuse a nomination is a separate decision and not MRT-reviewable because it is not prescribed under s.338(9) of the Act. Furthermore, if the decision to refuse the nomination was an MRT-reviewable decision, it could only have been reviewable by virtue of s.338(9). If it were so prescribed, only the nominator (that is, the business sponsor or the employer as prescribed persons under s.347(2)(d)) could seek review.

In response (dated 5 October 2008) to the Tribunal's invitation, the applicant submitted that the Tribunal's interpretation of the Federal Court decision in Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 (Lander J, 9 March 2007) (Kim (No. 7) was incorrect. The applicant also claimed that a decision to refuse an onshore Subclass 442 application is MRT reviewable and that this may include a review of the nomination. Whether the Tribunal has jurisdiction to consider and approve a nomination for the purposes of cl.422.222 has been the subject of diverging views in the Courts. The leading authority on this issue indicates that nominations that are refused are not reviewable by the MRT. In Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 (Lander J, 9 March 2007) (Kim (No. 7) Lander J found that a decision to refuse a nomination is a separate decision and not MRT-reviewable because it is not prescribed under s.338(9) of the Act. Furthermore, if the decision to refuse the nomination was an MRT-reviewable decision, it could only have been reviewable by virtue of s.338(9). If it were so prescribed, only the nominator (that is, the business sponsor or the employer as prescribed persons under s.347(2)(d)) could seek review.

Given that the visa applicant failed to provide comments within the prescribed time frame, the Tribunal has proceeded to make a decision, without taking any further action, pursuant to section 359C of the Act. If, despite failing to provide comments within the prescribed time frame, the Tribunal still has a discretion to invite the visa applicant to appear before the Tribunal, given the decision by the Federal Court in Kim v MIAC (2007) FCA 138 the Tribunal has proceeded to make a decision, without taking any further action including proceeding to hearing, pursuant to section 359C of the Act. A recent judgement by the Federal Court in Kim v MIAC (2007) FCA 138 states that the nomination refusal is not reviewable because it is not an MRT reviewable decision and if it was reviewable, it is only reviewable at the instigation of the nominator only. Accordingly, there is no evidence that a nomination in respect of occupational training has been lodged and has been approved. Accordingly, the visa applicant cannot meet clause 442.222. A recent judgement by the Federal Court in Kim v MIAC (2007) FCA 138 states that the nomination refusal is not reviewable because it was not an MRT reviewable decision and it was only reviewable at the instigation of the nominator only. Previous decisions of the Federal Court stated that refusal nominations for occupational training are reviewable by the Tribunal (see Tvarkovsky v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (2001) FCA 375 (4 April 2001) and PMA4/2001)).

Whether the Tribunal has jurisdiction to consider and approve a nomination for the purposes of cl.422.222 has been the subject of diverging views in the Courts. The leading authority on this issue indicates that nominations that are refused are not reviewable by the MRT. In Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 (Lander J, 9 March 2007) (Kim (No. 7) Lander J found that a decision to refuse a nomination is a separate decision and not MRT-reviewable because it is not prescribed under s.338(9) of the Act. Furthermore, if the decision to refuse the nomination was an MRT-reviewable decision, it could only have been reviewable by virtue of s.338(9). If it were so prescribed, only the nominator (that is, the business sponsor or the employer as prescribed persons under s.347(2)(d)) could seek review.

Whether the Tribunal has jurisdiction to consider and approve a nomination for the purposes of cl.442.222 has been the subject of diverging views in the Courts. The leading authority on this issue indicates that nominations that are refused are not reviewable by the MRT. In Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 (Lander J, 9 March 2007) (Kim (No. 7) Lander J found that a decision to refuse a nomination is a separate decision and not MRT-reviewable because it is not prescribed under s.338(9) of the Act. Furthermore, if the decision to refuse the nomination was an MRT-reviewable decision, it could only have been reviewable by virtue of s.338(9). If it were so prescribed, only the nominator (that is, the business sponsor or the employer as prescribed persons under s.347(2)(d)) could seek review.

Prior to the decision of Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 , it was considered that decisions to refuse nominations for occupational training were reviewable by the Tribunal (see Tvarkovsky v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (2001) FCA 375 (4 April 2001) and PMA4/2001)). The Tribunal considers that the applicant has provided evidence indicating that she has ongoing occupational training, comprising her TAFE studies and workplace training. In such circumstances, the Tribunal may have approved the nomination for occupational training and considers it unfortunate that it was refused by the delegate given that there was evidence provided to the Department establishing the applicant's ongoing training. However, as previously stated, the Tribunal is unable to review the Department's refusal of the nomination for workplace training made by Strobe Hair. In response, dated 13 May 2008, to the Tribunal' s s.359A letter, the applicant's representative submitted that the Tribunal's interpretation of the Federal Court decision in Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 (Lander J, 9 March 2007) (Kim (No. 7) is incorrect. The representative also refers to Departmental policy which states that a decision to refuse an onshore Subclass 442 application is MRT reviewable and that this may include a review of the nomination. Whether the Tribunal has jurisdiction to consider and approve a nomination for the purposes of cl.422.222 has been the subject of diverging views in the Courts. The leading authority on this issue indicates that nominations that are refused are not reviewable by the MRT. In Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 (Lander J, 9 March 2007) (Kim (No. 7) Lander J found that a decision to refuse a nomination is a separate decision and not MRT-reviewable because it is not prescribed under s.338(9) of the Act. Furthermore, if the decision to refuse the nomination was an MRT-reviewable decision, it could only have been reviewable by virtue of s.338(9). If it were so prescribed, only the nominator (that is, the business sponsor or the employer as prescribed persons under s.347(2)(d)) could seek review.

Tribunal's evidence, findings and comments The Tribunal had regard to the information provided by the applicant to the Department relating to her application for occupational training in Australia. The Tribunal noted that the applicant: did not provide any detail about the proposed training and whether it would enhance her skills, or about the capacity of the nominator to provide training; did not provide any detail about why she believed the occupational opportunities available to Australian residents would not be adversely affected, except that she would return to Korea at the end of her training; did not avail herself of the opportunity to present arguments to the Tribunal. The Tribunal made the following findings and comments: it was bound by the Federal Court decision in Kim v Minister for Immigration [2007] FCA 138 ; it was not satisfied that there was any evidence before it that indicated that the applicant's nomination had been approved by the Minister. For that reason, it found that there was not an approved nomination for occupational training by Transworld and therefore the applicant did not meet subclause 442.222(1); it acknowledged that prior to Kim , decisions to refuse nominations for occupational training were reviewable by the Tribunal (see Tvarkovsky v Minister for Immigration [2001] FCA 365). It considered the guidelines in PAM3 to determine whether the nomination could be approved; it was not satisfied on the evidence before it that occupational training opportunities available to Australian citizens would not be adversely affected if the visa was granted.

The leading authority on this question indicates that nominations that are refused are not reviewable by the Tribunal. In Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 [Kim (No.7]) the Federal Court, in its appellate jurisdiction found that a decision to refuse a nomination is a separate decision and not MRT-reviewable because it is not prescribed under s.338(9) of the Act. Furthermore, if the decision to refuse the nomination was an MRT-reviewable decision, it could only have been reviewable by virtue of s.338(9). If it were so prescribed, only the nominator (that is, the business sponsor or the employer as prescribed persons under s.347(2)(d)) could seek review.

However, more recently in Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 the Federal Court, in its appellate jurisdiction, held that the decision on the nomination in relation to a subclass 442 occupational trainee visa is a separate decision that is not an MRT-reviewable decision and, if it is, it is only reviewable by the nominator.

In Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 (Federal Court of Australia, Lander J, 9 March 2007), an appeal from a decision of the Federal Magistrate dismissing an application for review of a decision by a previously constituted Tribunal, Lander J found that the decision to refuse the nomination was not an MRT reviewable decision as it was not prescribed under subsection 338(9) of the Act. The Court also found that the only person who might have sought review of the decision to refuse the nomination was the business sponsor or the employer because only they are prescribed persons for the purpose of para.347(2)(d) of the Act. The Tribunal considers that it is bound by the decision in Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 because, although it appears to be contrary to the decision of Lee v MIMIA [2006] which followed Tvarkovsky v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (2001) FCA 375 , it is a judgment of the Federal Court in its appellate jurisdiction and is thus the leading authority on this issue. The Tribunal is not satisfied that there is any evidence before it that indicates that the applicant's nomination has been approved by the Minister. The Tribunal therefore finds that there is not an approved nomination for occupational training by Transworld Australia Pty Ltd and the applicant does not meet subclause 442.222(1). Therefore, the applicant does not meet clause 442.222. In Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 (Federal Court of Australia, Lander J, 9 March 2007), an appeal from a decision of the Federal Magistrate dismissing an application for review of a decision by a previously constituted Tribunal, Lander J found that the decision to refuse the nomination was not an MRT reviewable decision as it was not prescribed under subsection 338(9) of the Act. The Court also found that the only person who might have sought review of the decision to refuse the nomination was the business sponsor or the employer because only they are prescribed persons for the purpose of para.347(2)(d) of the Act. The Tribunal considers that it is bound by the decision in Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 because, although it appears to be contrary to the decision of Lee v MIMIA [2006] which followed Tvarkovsky v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (2001) FCA 375 , it is a judgment of the Federal Court in its appellate jurisdiction and is thus the leading authority on this issue. The Tribunal is not satisfied that there is any evidence before it that indicates that the applicant's nomination has been approved by the Minister. The Tribunal therefore finds that there is not an approved nomination for occupational training by Transworld Australia Pty Ltd and the applicant does not meet subclause 442.222(1). Therefore, the applicant does not meet clause 442.222.

The Tribunal considers that it is bound by the decision in Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 because, although it appears to be contrary to the decision of Lee v MIMIA [2006] which followed Tvarkovsky v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (2001) FCA 375 , it is a judgment of the Federal Court in its appellate jurisdiction and is thus the leading authority on this issue. In Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 (Federal Court of Australia, Lander J, 9 March 2007), an appeal from a decision of the Federal Magistrate dismissing an application for review of a decision by a previously constituted Tribunal, Lander J found that the decision to refuse the nomination was not an MRT reviewable decision as it was not prescribed under s.338(9) of the Act.

The Tribunal considers that it is bound by the decision in Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 because, although it appears to be contrary to the decision of Lee v MIMIA [2006] which followed Tvarkovsky v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (2001) FCA 375 , it is a judgment of the Federal Court in its appellate jurisdiction and is thus the leading authority on this issue. In Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 (Federal Court of Australia, Lander J, 9 March 2007), an appeal from a decision of the Federal Magistrate dismissing an application for review of a decision by a previously constituted Tribunal, Lander J found that the decision to refuse the nomination was not an MRT reviewable decision as it was not prescribed under subsection 338(9) of the Act.

The Tribunal considers that it is bound by the decision in Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 because, although it appears to be contrary to the decision of Lee v MIMIA [2006] which followed Tvarkovsky v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (2001) FCA 375 , it is a judgment of the Federal Court in its appellate jurisdiction and is thus the leading authority on this issue. In Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 (Federal Court of Australia, Lander J, 9 March 2007), an appeal from a decision of the Federal Magistrate dismissing an application for review of a decision by a previously constituted Tribunal, Lander J found that the decision to refuse the nomination was not an MRT reviewable decision as it was not prescribed under s.338(9) of the Act. Prior to the decision of Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 , it was considered that decisions to refuse nominations for occupational training were reviewable by the Tribunal (see Tvarkovsky v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (2001) FCA 375 (4 April 2001) and PMA4/2001)).

In Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 (Federal Court of Australia, Lander J, 9 March 2007), an appeal from a decision of the Federal Magistrate dismissing an application for review of a decision by a previously constituted Tribunal, Lander J found that the decision to refuse the nomination was not an MRT reviewable decision as it was not prescribed under s.338(9) of the Act. Prior to the decision of Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 , it was considered that decisions to refuse nominations for occupational training were reviewable by the Tribunal (see Tvarkovsky v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (2001) FCA 375 (4 April 2001) and PMA4/2001)). The Tribunal considers that it is bound by the decision in Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 because, although it appears to be contrary to the decision of Lee v MIMIA [2006] which followed Tvarkovsky v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (2001) FCA 375 , it is a judgment of the Federal Court in its appellate jurisdiction and is thus the leading authority on this issue.

The Tribunal considers that it is bound by the decision in Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 because, although it appears to be contrary to the decision of Lee v MIMIA [2006] which followed Tvarkovsky v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (2001) FCA 375 , it is a judgment of the Federal Court in its appellate jurisdiction and is thus the leading authority on this issue. In Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 (Federal Court of Australia, Lander J, 9 March 2007), an appeal from a decision of the Federal Magistrates Court dismissing an application for review of a decision by a previously constituted Tribunal, Lander J found that the decision to refuse the nomination in respect of an occupational trainee was not an MRT reviewable decision as it was not prescribed under s.338(9) of the Act.
accordance with the judgement of the Federal Court of Australia in Kim v MIAC &Anor [2007] FCA 138 , the Tribunal does not consider that it has jurisdiction to review the decision to refuse the nomination lodged by MBKIM.Com Pty Ltd on your behalf. As indicated above, the decision of Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 is contrary to earlier decisions on the issue.

As indicated above, the decision of Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 is contrary to earlier decisions on the issue. In Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 (Federal Court of Australia, Lander J, 9 March 2007), an appeal from a decision of the Federal Magistrates Court dismissing an application for review of a decision by a previously constituted Tribunal, Lander J found that the decision to refuse the nomination in respect of an occupational trainee was not an MRT reviewable decision as it was not prescribed under s.338(9) of the Act. The Tribunal considers that it is bound by the decision in Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 because, although it appears to be contrary to the decision of Lee v MIMIA [2006] which followed Tvarkovsky v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (2001) FCA 375 , it is a judgment of the Federal Court in its appellate jurisdiction and is thus the leading authority on this issue.
In accordance with the judgement of the Federal Court of Australia in Kim v MIAC &Anor [2007] FCA 138 , the Tribunal considers that it does not have jurisdiction to review the decision to refuse the nomination lodged by MBKIM.Com Pty Ltd on your behalf.

Without an approved nomination the visa applicant cannot meet clause 442.222 and the application cannot succeed. In Tvarkovski v MIMIA [2001] FCA 375 , the Federal Court held that where the approval of a nomination is at issue, the Tribunal should consider for itself whether the occupational training nomination should be approved for the purposes of cl.442.222. However, in Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 , Lander J found that a decision to refuse a nomination is a separate decision that is not an MRT-reviewable decision and, if it is, it is only reviewable by the nominator. As Kim is a judgment of the Federal Court in its appellate jurisdiction, the Tribunal considers itself bound by the reasoning of Lander J in respect of the reviewability of the nomination.
The Tribunal found on the basis of the decision of the Federal Court in Kim v The Minister for Immigration [2007] FCA 138 that it could not review the nomination decision.

The Tribunal is bound by the decision in Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 because, although it appears to be contrary to the decision of Lee v MIMIA [2006] FMCA 1395 which followed Tvarkovsky v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (2001) FCA 375 , it is a judgment of the Federal Court in its appellate jurisdiction and is thus the leading authority on this issue. In Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 (Federal Court of Australia, Lander J, 9 March 2007), an appeal from a decision of the Federal Magistrate dismissing an application for review of a decision by a previously constituted Tribunal, Lander J found that the decision to refuse the nomination was not an MRT reviewable decision as it was not prescribed under s.338(9) of the Act. Prior to the decision of Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 , it was considered that decisions to refuse nominations for occupational training were reviewable by the Tribunal (see Tvarkovsky v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (2001) FCA 375.

Prior to the decision of Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 , it was considered that decisions to refuse nominations for occupational training were reviewable by the Tribunal (see Tvarkovsky v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (2001) FCA 375 (4 April 2001) and PMA4/2001)). The Tribunal considers that it is bound by the decision in Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 because, although it appears to be contrary to the decision of Lee v MIMIA [2006] which followed Tvarkovsky v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (2001) FCA 375 , it is a judgment of the Federal Court in its appellate jurisdiction and is thus the leading authority on this issue. In Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 (Federal Court of Australia, Lander J, 9 March 2007), an appeal from a decision of the Federal Magistrate dismissing an application for review of a decision by a previously constituted Tribunal, Lander J found that the decision to refuse the nomination was not an MRT reviewable decision as it was not prescribed under s.338(9) of the Act. The Tribunal's letter was sent to the visa applicant on this basis prior to the decision of Kim v MIAC [2007] FCA 138 coming to the Tribunal's attention.
I am satisfied that this court does not have jurisdiction to entertain that application (see Kim v Minister for Immigration & Citizenship [2007] FCA 138 per Lander J at [18] and [19]).

A recent judgement by the Federal Court in Kim v MIAC (2007) FCA 138 states that the nomination refusal is not reviewable because it was not an MRT reviewable decision and it was only reviewable at the instigation of the nominator only. Accordingly, there is no evidence that a nomination in respect of occupational training has been lodged and has been approved. Accordingly, the visa applicant cannot meet clause 442.222. A recent judgement by the Federal Court in Kim v MIAC (2007) FCA 138 states that the nomination refusal is not reviewable because it was not an MRT reviewable decision and it was only reviewable at the instigation of the nominator only. Previous decisions of the Federal Court stated that refusal nominations for occupational training are reviewable by the Tribunal (see Tvarkovsky v Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs (2001) FCA 375 (4 April 2001) and PMA4/2001)).
